00001 #ifndef __COIN_H__
00002 #define __COIN_H__
00003 
00004 #include "ceal.h"
00005 
00006 /* Coins -- Allow self-adjusting programs to make random decisions
00007    while maintaining necessary stability.
00008 
00009    Once a coin has been constructed (which is usually random), the
00010    user can "flip" a coin deterministically by supplying a word-value
00011    [x] (see: [coin_flip]).  The outcome of a flip given an [x] will
00012    either be 0 or 1.  Given the same [x] and the same coin, the
00013    outcome will always be the same.  Since a coin is deterministic,
00014    the program using such a coin is stable in the sense than
00015    re-evaluation of any series of identitical flips will yield
00016    identitical results.
00017 
00018    Each coin also carries a bias which controls the expected outcome
00019    of coin flips (expectation taken over all values of [x]).  A bias
00020    of 1 isn't interesting, any coin flip will yield 0. A bias of 2
00021    will yield a fair coin where the outcome of a flip is equally
00022    likely to be 0 or 1.  A biased coin is one where the bias is
00023    greater than 2, in which case the outcome of a coin flip is more
00024    likely to be 1 than 0.
00025 */
00026 
00027 typedef struct coin_s coin_t;
00028 
00029 coin_t* Coin_fair();
00030 coin_t* Coin_biased_4();
00031 coin_t* Coin_biased_8();
00032 coin_t* Coin_biased_16();
00033 
00034 /* Coin flipping -- given a word [x], flips the coin deterministically
00035    for [x] and returns either 1 or 0.  If the coin is biased, the
00036    expected number of 0's (expectation taken over all possible values
00037    for [x]) is _less_ than the number of 1's.  Higher biases will
00038    yield lower expectations of flipping a 0. */
00039 int coin_flip(coin_t* coin, void* x);
00040 
00041 #endif
